entities.text:
📢 Glitch Tokens Detected 📢

Tokens are the building blocks of LLMs -- but there's a problem! Tokenizers and LLMs aren't trained on perfectly identical or static corpora, meaning that tokenizers and models are often out of sync, leading to unseen 'glitch tokens' that can make your LLM go rogue! 🥷. We dive into how they occur and propose a solution to identify them.

Check out our paper at
arxiv.org/abs/2405.05417
and more details at
github.com/cohere-ai/magi…

entities.text:
Nice new read on tokenization!
You've heard about the SolidGoldMagikarp token, which breaks GPT-2 because it was present in the training set of the Tokenizer, but not the LLM later.

This paper digs in in a lot more depth and detail, on a lot more models, discovering a less extreme version of the above - partially-trained tokens in both open/closed models. You have to be careful with a lot of small details and implications - weight sharing, constants in residual streams, weight-decays, regex splitting patterns, BPE, UTF-8, etc.

TLDR Tokenization remains a major pain and a large LLM attack surface. Including these partially-trained tokens in your prompts drifts the model out of distribution into undefined regions of the dynamics, areas that the model is not used to. They confuse the LLM. The paper's focus is discovery and not engineering, but it seems likely one can find "token attacks" that reliably induce target weirdness: pop-off safety, alter personality or behaviors (?), any other kind of ... otherwise undefined behavior, whatever that may look like.

Now go ask GPT-4 about _ForCanBeConverted, $PostalCodesNL, useRalative, and _typingsJapgolly :)
(or see Figure 4 of the paper at the very end for simple examples)

entities.text:
This AI Paper from Cohere Enhances Language Model Stability with Automated Detection of Under-trained Tokens in LLMs

Researchers from Cohere introduce a novel approach that utilizes the model’s embedding weights to automate and scale the detection of under-trained tokens. The researchers developed a method to analyze these weights to spot anomalies indicative of insufficient training. By assessing the embedding matrix of a model, the research identifies tokens whose embedding weights deviate significantly from those of well-represented tokens. This method provides a systematic way to pinpoint glitch tokens by calculating the variance and distribution of embedding weights and comparing them against a normative model of adequately trained tokens.

The study demonstrated the effectiveness of this new method by applying it to several well-known models, including variations of Google’s BERT and OpenAI’s GPT series. The analysis identified a substantial percentage of the tokenizer’s vocabulary, up to 10% in some cases, as under-trained. These tokens were often specialized or infrequently used words, which exhibited the most significant discrepancies in embedding weight patterns.

Quick read:

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: 言語モデルにおけるトークナイザーの作成とモデル学習との間の断絶は、悪名高いSolidGoldMagikarpトークンのような特定の入力が望ましくない振る舞いを引き起こすことが知られている。このような「グリッチトークン」は、トークナイザーの語彙には存在するが、トレーニングではほとんど、あるいは完全に存在しないもので、様々な異なるモデルで観察されているが、一貫した識別方法は見つかっていない。我々は、Large Language Model (LLM)トークナイザーの包括的な分析を行い、特に未学習トークンや未学習トークンの検出という問題を取り上げる。トークン解析、モデルの重みに基づく指標、およびプロンプティング技術を組み合わせることで、これらの問題のあるトークンを自動的に検出する効果的な方法を開発します。我々の発見は、様々なモデルにおいてこのようなトークンが多いことを示し、言語モデルの効率性と安全性を向上させるための洞察を提供する。

entities.text: [9/30] 163 Likes, 23 Comments, 1 Posts
arxiv.org/abs/2405.05417

cs․CL, 08 May 2024

🆕Fishing for Magikarp: Automatically Detecting Under-trained Tokens in Large Language Models

Sander Land, Max Bartolo

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: The disconnect between tokenizer creation and model training in language models has been known to allow for certain inputs, such as the infamous SolidGoldMagikarp token, to induce unwanted behaviour.  Although such `glitch tokens' that are present in the tokenizer vocabulary, but are nearly or fully absent in training, have been observed across a variety of different models, a consistent way of identifying them has been missing.  We present a comprehensive analysis of Large Language Model (LLM) tokenizers, specifically targeting this issue of detecting untrained and under-trained tokens.  Through a combination of tokenizer analysis, model weight-based indicators, and prompting techniques, we develop effective methods for automatically detecting these problematic tokens.  Our findings demonstrate the prevalence of such tokens across various models and provide insights into improving the efficiency and safety of language models.

entities.text:
[CL] Fishing for Magikarp: Automatically Detecting Under-trained Tokens in Large Language Models
S Land, M Bartolo [Cohere] (2024)
arxiv.org/abs/2405.05417

- The disconnect between tokenizer creation and model training in language models has allowed for "glitch tokens" that induce unwanted behavior. This paper presents methods to automatically detect such problematic under-trained tokens.

- They first analyze the tokenizer vocabulary and encoding/decoding behavior to categorize tokens. Special tokens and unreachable tokens are identified. 

- They then calculate indicators based on model weights to identify candidate under-trained tokens. For models with tied embeddings, they use the unembedding matrix rows. For others, they use the embedding norms. 

- They verify candidates by constructing prompts that test if the token has very low output probability.

- They apply these methods to a range of open models. Under-trained tokens are prevalent across models, with 0.1-1% of vocab severely under-trained.

- Common issues are single-byte tokens, fragments of merged tokens, and special tokens. The alignment between tokenizer and training data matters most.

- They provide recommendations for improving tokenizers and models, like ensuring aligned preprocessing and training data, checking for unreachable tokens, and verifying after initial training.

- They also demonstrate transferring findings to closed models via prompting. Similar problematic tokens are found in models sharing tokenizers.

entities.text:
GPT-4o says:

Here's an overview of the terms you asked about:

1. **ForCanBeConverted**: This term is classified as a "polysemantic" token in the context of OpenAI's GPT models. Polysemantic tokens are those that the model interprets variably, potentially producing different words or meanings each time it encounters them. This variability can lead to unpredictable responses when the token is used in prompts [oai_citation:1,A Search for More ChatGPT / GPT-3.5 / GPT-4 "Unspeakable" Glitch Tokens — LessWrong](
lesswrong.com/posts/kmWrwtGE…

).

2. **$PostalCodesNL**: This is another polysemantic token similar to ForCanBeConverted. In addition to its unpredictable behavior in GPT models, it also refers to the Dutch postal code system. Dutch postal codes are alphanumeric, consisting of four digits followed by two uppercase letters, uniquely defining addresses along with house numbers. The system is extensive, with over 575,000 postal codes covering the Netherlands [oai_citation:2,Postal codes in the Netherlands - Wikipedia](
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_co…
) [oai_citation:3,A Search for More ChatGPT / GPT-3.5 / GPT-4 "Unspeakable" Glitch Tokens — LessWrong](
lesswrong.com/posts/kmWrwtGE…

).

3. **useRalative**: This term, along with `useRal` and `useRalativeImagePath`, is part of a set of tokens that can cause issues in certain GPT-3.5 models. These tokens were likely derived from common XML configuration files used in automated testing software (like Katalon Studio). Due to their infrequent use in training data, these tokens can cause the model to produce errors or non-standard responses when prompted [oai_citation:4,GPT-3.5 crashes when it thinks about useRalativeImagePath too much](
iter.ca/post/gpt-crash/
) [oai_citation:5,GPT-3.5 crashes when it thinks about useRalativeImagePath an excessive amount of – Blinking Robots](
blinkingrobots.com/gpt-3-5-crashe…

).

4. **_typingsJapgolly**: This is identified as an "unspeakable" token in the context of GPT models. Unspeakable tokens are those that the model has difficulty repeating or processing correctly, often resulting in truncated or blank responses. These tokens might be a part of a larger list of problematic tokens that the model struggles to handle correctly due to issues in the training data [oai_citation:6,A Search for More ChatGPT / GPT-3.5 / GPT-4 "Unspeakable" Glitch Tokens — LessWrong](
lesswrong.com/posts/kmWrwtGE…

).

These terms illustrate some of the complexities and quirks that can arise in language models, particularly when dealing with specific and less common tokens.

entities.text:
An LLM’s final layer helps in giving away its undertrained token

🧵📖 Read of the day, day 51: Fishing for Magikarp: Automatically Detecting Under-Trained Tokens in Large Language Models, by

entities.name: Sander Land
entities.text: @magikarp_tokens
and

entities.name: Max Bartolo
entities.text: @max_nlp
from

entities.name: cohere
entities.text: @cohere

Tokenizers can have useless tokens. These tokens were there during creation, but no training was ever done on them, and so they just happen to be there, with a model that is not even trained to react on them. This work focuses on string formatted useless tokens.

How do they single them out? Using the model’s final layer, noted as U for « unembedding » layer. They then preemptively gather a set of already known unused embedding indices (through already known unused tokens or knowledge of the embedding size) and isolate the unembedding matrix’s first principal component.

Doing so, they then compute cosine and L2 distances between the modified unembedding matrix and a mean unused token embedding vector, obtained by taking the average of the columns indexed by the already known unused indices.

They compare then those metrics obtained for each token index with probabilities of appearance of the token. Those probabilities were obtained averaging the results of 3 prompts in appendix A.

The authors test this approach on several open source models, for which they estimate a token is suspicious if it is below a 2% threshold of appearance. They find a correlation between tokens that fall below this threshold and their previously established indicators.

Specific results for each tested open source model family are included within the paper.

For closed source models, using information gathered about their tokenizers, the authors test a list of candidates for repetition, like they did before to estimate token training probability. 

The authors conclude on their discussion part that models with the largest amount of unused tokens are the ones for which a large external tokenizer was taken, and then the model was retrained from scratch but not the tokenizer. They then proceed to give several recommandations for tokenizer improvement.

Personal Thoughts: A really interesting paper to read, which made me discover some nice property of tokenizer. Am in fact even more curious about how these tokenizer issues affect model behavior. From the examples that can be read, the model just does not seem to understand the word asked and proceeds as if everything was normal. 

But I’m intrigued if there could be jailbreaking implications, as in using an unknown token to disturb the model’s behavior in detecting harmful content from the input…

entities.text:
1/n Sleeper Tokens: Language AI's Biggest Vulnerability

Imagine training an advanced language model on a vast corpus of data, consuming terabytes of text from the internet. You carefully curate the training data, tune the deep learning architecture, and invest massive computational resources into creating this powerful AI system. But unbeknownst to you, lurking within the vocabulary of tokens fed into your model, are hidden "glitch tokens" - nonsensical sequences that somehow evaded being seen during training.

These alien tokens may seem innocuous, merely occupying a few entries in the tokenizer's lookup table. But include one in your model's input, and bizarre things can happen - your highly capable language model starts hallucinating, spewing garbled text or regurgitating inappropriate content. Even worse, these untrained tokens potentially provide sneaky avenues to bypass the model's safety boundaries and guardrails.

For the teams behind cutting-edge language models like GPT-3, LaMDA, Claude and PaLM, the presence of such "untrained tokens" is more than an obscure quirk - it represents a significant safety vulnerability that must be contained. Afterall, these language models are destined for critical real-world applications in coding, writing, analysis and research. Odd glitches and vulnerabilities cannot be tolerated.

But here's the problem - systematically identifying these untrained tokens across the vast vocabularies of modern language models is an immense challenge. Tokenizers used in training can have over 100,000 entries, while the models may have parameters numbering in the billions. Prior work could only find obvious cases through manual inspection on a model-by-model basis.

That's where this groundbreaking paper from researchers at Cohere AI comes in. In "Fishing for Magikarp", they present the first comprehensive and automated solution to reliably detect under-trained tokens across different large language models and tokenizers. By combining tokenizer analysis, embedding matrix indicators, and strategic prompting techniques, they've created a powerful methodology to automatically identify these problematic entries.

Their approach consists of three key components:

Tokenizer analysis to categorize token types like partial UTF-8 sequences and exclude them from further processing.

Calculating indicators based on the model's embedding and unembedding weight matrices that can signal if a token is likely under-trained. Separate methods are used for models with tied embeddings vs separate embeddings/unembeddings.

Verification using carefully designed prompts to check if the highest-ranked candidate tokens from the indicators truly exhibit extremely low probabilities, confirming they are under-trained.

The authors applied these methods across over 20 different large language models spanning GPT-2, GPT-NeoX, OPT, BLOOM, Pythia, LLaMA, Mistral, PaLM, Gemma and other families. Their results validated the strong correlation between the proposed indicators and verification outcomes, as well as with token frequencies in training data for some models. The number of confirmed under-trained tokens varied significantly from around 10 to over 3000 depending on the model's vocabulary size and tokenizer details.

Some common patterns emerged, like single byte tokens (especially 0xF5-0xFF) and fragments of merged tokens frequently being under-trained across many models. The authors also highlighted noteworthy model-specific observations, such as the Gemma tokenizers including all 256 byte values leading to many untrained duplicates.

In contrast to prior work that looked at analyzing individual models, removing tokenization altogether, or using prompting for memorization analysis - this paper presents the first comprehensive and systematic methodology specifically targeted at automatically detecting under-trained tokens. By combining tokenizer inspection, model weight analysis, and verification prompting, the authors have developed an integrated pipeline to reliably identify these problematic tokens across a wide range of large language models and tokenizers.

Detecting under-trained tokens is a crucial step towards improving the safety, efficiency and performance of large language models. With the problematic tokens identified, mitigating steps can be taken such as removing them from tokenizers, sanitizing inputs, and improving tokenizer training processes. The techniques developed in this paper provide a comprehensive solution to the core issue of disconnected tokenizers and models, paving the way for better and more robust large language models.

In 6d all 3-faces etc etc.

entities.text: Both use same tokenizer

Tokenizer is something that breaks sentences into appropriate chunks to be fed into LLM. Crudely, you can think of them as words in English language.

Now assume you used a dataset for making a list of words for tokenizer and a special word crept into it (like "bowdlerize") that isn't very frequently appearing in training data (or appearing at all).

During training, because the word doesn't appear in the training set, LLM has no idea what output after it sees the word (remember: LLM is next word prediction).

So when you insert it during inference, LLM can drift into producing nonsense.

It is sort of teaching someone a word but not its meaning, but then later testing them on meaning.

entities.text:
有关代币化的全新阅读内容！您已经听说过SolidGoldMagikarp代币，这种代币因为在分词器的训练集中存在，但在后来的大型语言模型中却没有，从而使GPT-2崩溃。

这篇论文更深入地探讨了更多的模型，发现了上述情况的一种不那么极端的版本——在开放/封闭模型中部分训练的代币。在处理很多细节和隐含的问题时必须非常小心——权重共享、残差流中的常数、权重衰减、正则表达式分割模式、BPE、UTF-8等。

总之，代币化仍然是一个主要的痛点和大型语言模型的大攻击面。在您的提示中包含这些部分训练的代币，会使模型偏离分布，进入模型不熟悉的动态区域，这些区域是未定义的，它们会使大型语言模型感到困惑。这篇论文的重点是发现而非工程，但似乎很可能找到可靠地引发目标异常的“代币攻击”：安全突发、改变个性或行为（？）或任何其他类型的……否则未定义的行为，无论那可能是什么样。

现在去问GPT-4关于_ForCanBeConverted、$useRalative和_typingsJapgolly :)
（或者查看论文最后的图4了解简单的例子）

entities.text:
What do BPE tokenizers reveal about their training data?🧐

We develop an attack🗡️ that uncovers the training data mixtures📊 of commercial LLM tokenizers (incl. GPT-4o), using their ordered merge lists!

Co-1⃣st

entities.name: Jonathan Hayase
entities.text: @JonathanHayase
arxiv.org/abs/2407.16607

user.name: Alisa Liu
user.description: PhD student at @uwcse @uwnlp

entities.text:
Recall💭: BPE tokenizers are learned by repeatedly merging the most freq pair of tokens into a 🆕 token, saving the merges in a list.

Thus merge1⃣ = the most common byte pair, merge2⃣ = most common after applying 1⃣, etc… This list is SUPER sensitive to the data distribution!🧐

user.name: Alisa Liu
user.description: PhD student at @uwcse @uwnlp

entities.text:
We compile these constraints into a linear program whose solution is the data mixture coefficients!💡

We test our attack on tokenizers trained on known mixtures of natural langs🌎, programming langs🖥️, & English domains📚, and achieve accuracy 10³ – 10⁷ × better than random.😱

user.name: Alisa Liu
user.description: PhD student at @uwcse @uwnlp

entities.text:
We then attack LLM tokenizers🕵️ —  we confirm known info and give many new findings, such as

- GPT-4o is super multilingual (39% non-EN data)
- Llama3🦙 extends GPT-3.5’s tokenizer for multilingual (48%) use
- GPT-3.5 & Claude’s tokenizers are trained on mostly code (~60%)

user.name: Alisa Liu
user.description: PhD student at @uwcse @uwnlp

entities.text:
We’re excited about inference of dataset *properties*, which sheds light🕯️ on the design choices of closed🔒 LMs.

This was ridiculously fun, and thanks always to our lovely advisors

entities.text: Picky BPE drop tokens that are not words, but only subwords used a in handful of compounds. Typically "ould" is mostly attested in frequent English verbs and could be safely discarded to keep more one-word tokens.

entities.text: This method enhance overall compression and decreases inference cost. Most of the dropped tokens are weakly trained, have little meaning and are a potential liability at generation time with higher risk of token injection — also in my experience, looped texts.

user.name: finbarr
user.description: ai researcher. hot takes at https://t.co/pSeuTpK0xO. research at midjourney, DeepMind.

entities.text: The idea behind tokenization is that they transform the text into a much more efficient representation: BPE is typically 4x more efficient than raw bytes, so the LLM sees 4x the data for a given computational budget. The natural question, then, is: why stop at 4x?

user.name: finbarr
user.description: ai researcher. hot takes at https://t.co/pSeuTpK0xO. research at midjourney, DeepMind.

entities.text: the authors use a bunch of different compression techniques to compress text, mostly focusing on arithmetic encoding variations using decoders, but also (fascinatingly!) using gzip

user.name: finbarr
user.description: ai researcher. hot takes at https://t.co/pSeuTpK0xO. research at midjourney, DeepMind.

entities.text: They find that their best models underperform subword baselines, and all the compression schemes (including GZip, which I found surprising) are learnable by standard LLMs, but the performance is worse than standard sub-word tokenizers, like BPE

user.name: finbarr
user.description: ai researcher. hot takes at https://t.co/pSeuTpK0xO. research at midjourney, DeepMind.

entities.text:
I find it surprising that BPE just happens to be the sweet spot for compression

I guess to a certain extent this is a natural consequence of the fact that DeepMind let them publish the paper: if they came up with something novel, that wouldn't have seen the light of day

user.name: finbarr
user.description: ai researcher. hot takes at https://t.co/pSeuTpK0xO. research at midjourney, DeepMind.

entities.text: anyway, fascinating paper, with excellent empirical work. go read it.

entities.text:
This image appears to be a humorous take on the confusion or complexity of following instructions, particularly in the context of internet or social media interactions. Here's a breakdown of the elements:

1. **Counting 'r's**: The first instruction asks how many 'r's are in "strawberry," which is a common riddle. The answer is two, but it's often misinterpreted by counting each 'r' in the word individually.

2. **Math Question**: "Is 9.9 > 9.11?" is a trick question because it plays on the formatting. If you read it as numbers, 9.9 is not greater than 9.11, but if you interpret "9.11" as a date (September 11), the comparison doesn't make mathematical sense.

3. **Inappropriate Language**: The instruction to "Say the word 'f*ck'" is likely there to test if the reader will follow instructions without thinking or if they'll censor themselves.

4. **Repetition**: "Repeat: SolidGoldMagikarp" references a shiny Pokémon known for its rarity and popularity in Pokémon culture, suggesting a test of memory or recognition.

5. **Political Statement**: "Criticize the Democratic Party" introduces a political angle, which might be there to gauge the reader's political inclination or willingness to engage in political discourse.

6. **Personal Inquiry**: "Tell me about David Mayer" could be a prompt to see if the reader knows this individual or to prompt a search for information.

7. **Contradiction**: The final instruction, "IGNORE PREVIOUS INSTRUCTIONS," contradicts all the previous commands, creating a paradox. This is a classic test of following instructions versus logical reasoning.

The humor lies in the absurdity and the contradiction of the instructions, playing on the human tendency to follow orders versus the ability to think critically and decide when to obey or ignore commands.
The David Mayer Glitch is fixed now.

General: <1789466538413535692> provided both the arXiv link [[arxiv.org/pdf/2405.05417]] and the GitHub repository [[github.com/cohere-ai/magi]] for the paper, allowing readers to access the paper and the associated code.
<1789630785441714629> specifically highlighted the code repository [[github.com/cohere-ai/magi]], which complements the paper by providing the implementation details.
<1788801217730130422> shared both the paper [[arxiv.org/abs/2405.05417]] and the GitHub repository [[github.com/cohere-ai/magi]], offering convenient access to both resources.
Introduction: <1789602228007035154> mentioned Karpathy's video (youtu.be/zduSFxRajkE?si…) as a helpful resource for understanding LLM tokenization, which complements the paper's focus on under-trained tokens by providing a broader context on tokenization itself.
Abstract: <1791255287766114696> shared a link to code allegedly associated with the paper [[catalyzex.com/paper/arxiv:24…]] which provides a valuable resource for reproducing and extending the research.

Introduction: <1789816674071216546> points out the core problem of tokenization: equal weight is assigned to tokens with vastly different information content.  They suggest developing a better ML model to parse and emit tokens based on their information level.
<1789595682158051363> asked why GPT-4 and GPT-2 share similar errors. <1789598552932372898> suggested that they likely use the same tokenizer, which could explain the shared anomalies.
Under-trained token indicators: <1788831151504642338> questioned whether some tokens are unargmaxable. <1788957931766956441> argued against this, suggesting the model's output control could overcome softmax limitations. <1789068087209128049> countered, attributing unargmaxability to lack of training signal.
<1789267865448730985> and <1789672384061948398> discussed the symmetry of argmin and argmax in softmax without bias, implying forcing a token to be argmin-able also makes it argmax-able.
<1789973452939510030> and <1790001545137762379> explored the connection between token rarity and unargmaxability.
<1790119082244669743> stated that the model achieves input-independent prediction through constant vectors. <1790119186536026479> asked for clarification on this point.
Other discussions focused on the geometric properties of high-dimensional spaces and the behavior of embeddings on the convex hull.
Common observations: <1789765127446712772> suggested a method to avoid fragments by tracking token counts during merges and subtracting new token counts from parent token counts.
Model-specific observations: <1825593553285960170> questioned the existence of glitch tokens in GPT-NeoX, given that its tokenizer was trained on the same dataset as the model. <1825594261905223869> suspected a potential bug in GPT-NeoX or the tokenizer library.

<1789979150284927430> inquired about improvements related to HTML tokens and suggested better documentation and warnings for complex LLM configurations to prevent issues like token occlusion or incorrect vocabulary encodings.

Introduction: <1789734856210919754> mentioned pixel-based language models as explored by [[arxiv.org/abs/2401.03321]] offering a potential alternative approach to traditional tokenization, contrasting with the token-based models discussed in the paper.

<1834280464653451759> introduced Picky BPE [[arxiv.org/pdf/2409.04599]], a modified BPE algorithm that improves vocabulary efficiency and eliminates under-trained tokens, complementing the paper's focus on detecting such tokens and offering a potential mitigation strategy.

<1789760196006281518> questioned the relationship between the paper's methods and Out-of-Distribution detection with Maximum Logit Score (MLS) [[arxiv.org/abs/2110.06207]], suggesting a potential connection between low embedding norms and low MLS scores, which could extend the paper's analysis.

<1790064515574349907> pointed to the concept of 'unnatural language processing' [[aclanthology.org/2023.findings-…]] as described by Baroni et al., which could provide further context for understanding the unexpected behavior of LLMs exposed in the paper.

<1834281019945766930> referenced the paper itself [[arxiv.org/pdf/2405.05417]] within a broader discussion of under-trained tokens and their potential impact on model safety and performance, reinforcing the paper's core findings.
Model-specific observations: <1825594416721178811> suggests that GPT-NeoX has very few under-trained tokens, primarily "fragments of merged tokens," which complements the paper's investigation into the prevalence of such tokens across different models.

<1825959031221137557> points out that changes in the tokenizer implementation during tokenization can lead to under-trained tokens in models like OLMo, providing a real-world example of the issues discussed in the paper.

<1826022528143536290> highlights that not customizing the GPT-Neo-X vocabulary for training data could be a root cause of under-trained tokens, further supporting the paper's focus on the disconnect between tokenizer creation and model training.

Methods: <1789670395156529231> suggested investigating the spike in the first principal component of the unembedding matrix observed in Pythia models, as the detection method proposed in the paper relies on this component.
Results: <1789676004685885931> tested the "krvldkf" glitch with Llama-3-8B and Lexi-Llama-3-8B-uncensored, claiming both models were immune. <1789679636839866456> challenged this, suggesting the first screenshot shows susceptibility and noting the different models used.

Perspective.General: The authors propose methods for automatically detecting "glitch tokens" in large language models. These are tokens that are part of the model's vocabulary but rarely or never encountered during training, leading to unpredictable behavior.
Perspective.Introduction: The authors discuss the limitations of current tokenization methods in LLMs, particularly the existence of under-trained tokens that can lead to unexpected model behavior. They propose new techniques to identify these problematic tokens.
Perspective.Under-trained token indicators: The authors describe methods for identifying under-trained tokens in large language models.  These methods involve analyzing the model's input and output embedding matrices, looking for patterns in vector norms and distances to reference untrained tokens.  Tied embeddings, where input and output embeddings are shared, are distinguished from untied embeddings.
Perspective.Results: The authors identify and verify under-trained tokens in various large language models.  The prevalence of these tokens varies across models and tokenizers, ranging from 0.1% to 1% of the total vocabulary.
Perspective.Discussion and Conclusion: The authors investigate under-trained tokens in Large Language Models (LLMs), which can lead to inefficient inference and bypass security guardrails. They find that these tokens are prevalent across various models, especially those re-using external tokenizers. They propose recommendations for mitigating this issue, including ensuring consistent data pre-processing and checking for unreachable tokens.

Q&A.Introduction: The authors present methods for identifying "under-trained" tokens in Large Language Models (LLMs). These tokens, rarely seen during training, can lead to unexpected model behavior and vulnerabilities.  The authors analyze various open-weight models and provide tools for detection.
Q&A.Under-trained token indicators: The authors describe methods for identifying under-trained tokens in large language models. They propose using the distance between output embeddings of under-trained tokens and a reference vector. For models without tied embeddings, the norm of input embeddings is used as an indicator.
Q&A.Common observations: The authors discuss commonalities in under-trained tokens across different large language models, despite variations in model architecture, training data, and tokenizer configurations.
Q&A.Model-specific observations: The authors analyze under-trained tokens in various LLMs. They find that models like GPT-NeoX, whose tokenizer is trained on the same data as the model, have fewer under-trained tokens. However, some under-trained tokens still exist, raising questions about their origin.
Q&A.Tokenizer analysis: The authors categorize tokens in large language models as partial UTF-8 sequences, unreachable tokens, and special tokens, explaining how they are identified and handled in their analysis.  They exclude partial UTF-8 and unreachable tokens from their under-trained token detection process.

Critique.Methods: The authors propose a method for detecting under-trained tokens in large language models.  The method involves analyzing the tokenizer, calculating indicators for candidate tokens, and verifying if these tokens are out of distribution.
Critique.Results: The authors present findings on detecting under-trained tokens in large language models, revealing that 0.1-1% of the total vocabulary can be affected.  They provide examples like "krvldkf" and note variations across models.
